items.description: Upper Bristol Avon area
items.message: This Flood Alert has been removed. River levels have fallen below flood alert threshold and there is no further rainfall currently forecast. We will continue to monitor the forecast and re-issue this alert if necessary. Our incident response staff are checking the condition of defences. Please see the GOV.UK website for a 5 day flood forecast.

items.description: Keswick Campsite
Upper River Derwent, Stonethwaite Beck and Derwent Water
items.message:
Lake levels on Derwent Water and river levels in Borrowdale continue to fall, but remain high due to recent rainfall.
Areas most at risk include low lying areas bordering the shores of Derwent Water and low lying areas in Borrowdale.
River and lake levels are expected to remain high throughout the week.
Further light rainfall is forecast throughout the weekend.
We will continue to monitor levels closely.
Avoid using low lying footpaths and any bridges near local watercourses and do not attempt to walk or drive through flood water.
This message will be updated by 10:00 AM on 25/11/2023, or as the situation changes.

items.description: River Lugg south of Leominster
items.message:
River levels remain high but are beginning to fall at the Lugwardine river gauge. Consequently, the risk of flooding remains.  We expect flooding to affect low lying land and roads adjacent to the River Lugg south of Leominster from Stoke Prior to Mordiford. Other locations that may be affected include Bodenham, Lugwardine and Hampton Bishop.   

The forecast is mainly dry with drizzle and showers possible over the next few days.

We are closely monitoring the situation.  

Please avoid contact with flood water and avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses.  

This message will be updated by 10:00 on 23/11/23, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Aldingbourne and Barnham Rifes
items.message: The Aldingbourne Rife remains high, but is slowly falling. Minor flooding is still affecting caravans at Riverside Caravan Centre and Rowan Park Caravan Park and could be affecting small parts of the Tesco car park on Shripney Road. The Barnham Rife is also slowly falling. Minor flood impacts will continue in Bersted. The next few days are expected to remain dry. Rain is expected on Monday 27/11/2023 but there is currently low confidence on rainfall totals. Water levels will remain higher than normal until at least the weekend and might rise again on Monday. The Aldingbourne Rife might not return to normal until December. Some roads will be affected by flood water, please plan to avoid driving through routes vulnerable to flooding, including Shripney Lane. We are running our pumps at Felpham and keeping grilles clear to help reduce the risk of flooding. We will update this message by 11:00 24/11/2023.

items.description: The tidal Rivers Bure, Ant and Thurne
items.message: This message has been issued because some minor flooding to riverside roads and footpaths is likely from now, 8am Friday 24th November, and for at least the next 24 hours. Water levels continue to remain high in this area. The forecast tides at Great Yarmouth will restrict the freshwater river drainage out to sea, resulting in higher than normal water levels within the Broads until the current high tides pass. We expect to see high water levels around Potter Heigham, Wroxham boat yards and Ferry Road in Horning. The current series of high spring tides will continue for the next few days and further warning messages may be issued. After the weekend the tides will start to fall away, allowing the freshwater river flows to drain out to sea at low tide as normal again. Take care on waterside roads and footpaths, and don't put yourself in unnecessary danger. We are closely monitoring the situation. We will update this message by 10am Saturday 25th November, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Eastern Yar
items.message: The water level in the Eastern Yar continues to broadly fall. In the last 24 hours, the level at Alverstone has fallen by 0.04m. At Sandown, the river has fallen by 0.08m in the same time period. Minor residual flooding impacts are still possible throughout the Yar Valley. Ditches around Fort Holiday Park may struggle to drain while the river remains higher than normal, but this should improve over the next 24 hours. The weather is now dry over the next 3 days. With no rain forecast in that time, the river has some chance to recover. Further rainfall is forecast for Hampshire and the Isle of Wight from Monday (27/11/2023). Should heavy rain affect the river then we may need to issue further advice. The river will remain sensitive to future rainfall, so please remain prepared for further flood risk this winter. We will continue to monitor the river and weather forecast information.

items.description: Groundwater flooding in the Upper Og Valley
items.message:
Groundwater levels have responded to recent rainfall and have remained high at our observation borehole in Draycot Foliat in the Og Valley area. Groundwater levels are above normal for this time of year and remain at a level where communities may be affected by flooding from groundwater over the coming days. Groundwater levels in the area are currently stable but remain responsive to rainfall. Further rainfall is forecast this morning, 18/11/23, with further unsettled weather expected over the coming week with low confidence over exact locations and timings of rain.

Groundwater level will continue to remain high and may still impact low lying gardens and cellars. Due to the nature of groundwater behaviour, this situation could continue for several weeks or longer.
We are continuing to monitor groundwater levels and will update this message by 25/11/2023, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Chertsey Bourne

floodArea.county: Bracknell Forest, Surrey, Windsor and Maidenhead

items.message:
Property flooding is not currently expected.

River levels remain high but are falling on the Chertsey Bourne. Flooding of roads and low lying land is expected to continue, especially in the Chertsey area. We expect river levels to remain high over the coming days.  It is forecast to be dry today (24/11/2023).

We are closely monitoring the situation. 

Please remain safe and aware of your local surroundings and refer to the 'River and Sea levels in England' webpage for current river levels. 

This message will be updated this evening (24/11/2023), or if the situation changes.

items.description: River Yeo and River Parrett Moors around Muchelney and Thorney
items.message:
The River Yeo level at Huish Episcopi Pumping Station is 7.93 m and is steady. The drain level is 7.60 m and continues to fall slowly.
Flooding will affect the road from Langport to Muchelney if this level exceeds 7.30 m, the road from Muchelney to Long Load above 7.86 m, and the road from Muchelney to Thorney above 7.93 m.
The weather forecast is dry for the next three to four days, apart from an occasional shower. The River Yeo at Muchelney is forecast to continue to fall as a result. Pumping continues at Huish Episcopi to reduce water levels on the Moors.  We will continue to operate the Parrett Flood Relief Channel as much as possible to evacuate water.
The situation is being continually monitored and staff are checking the condition of flood banks, spillways and weed screens. Please refer to @TravelSomerset for information on local road closures.
For water levels on the River Yeo and the drain at Huish Episcopi pumping station please refer to our website: (check-for-flooding.service.gov.uk/river-and-sea-levels).
This message will be updated by 13:00 on Friday 24/11/2023.

items.description: Slad Brook
items.message: River levels remain high due to rises at the Slad Steanbridge Lane river gauge as a result of recent heavy rainfall. Consequently, flooding of roads and farmland is possible. We are closely monitoring the situation. Please avoid contact with flood water. This message will be updated by 10 am on Saturday 25/11/23 or as the situation changes.

items.description: Creyke, Mill and Broadlane Becks at Cottingham
items.message: River levels remain high on Creyke, Mill and Broadlane Becks at Cottingham due to rainfall over the weekend. The area most at risk is properties around King Street, Northgate, Dunswell Road and North Moor Lane. There is no significant rain forecast for the next few days and we continue to monitor the forecast. Please consider putting your flood plan into action and avoid using low-lying footpaths near local watercourses.  We will update this message by 5pm on 24/11/2023, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Hunstanton coast in Norfolk
items.message: Large waves and sea spray are expected to affect the seafront between 14:45pm and 16:45pm today, Friday 24 November. Areas most at risk are around Hunstanton seafront. Flood gates in the area will be closed by the Local Authority which will make access difficult. The detailed forecast for those that use it is for a peak level of 3.89mAODN at 15:45pm, on Friday 24 November, which is 1.0 m above tide tables, wind Force 8, Northerly. (mAODN is height above average sea level, for more info refer to local tide tables). The following tide on Saturday at 04:15 am is currently forecast to be above the Flood Alert threshold. Take care on beaches, coastal roads and footpaths, and don't put yourself or others in danger. We are monitoring the situation and not expecting it to escalate.  We will update this message by 7pm today, Friday 24 November.

items.description: The tidal River Yare from Thorpe St Andrew to Breydon Water
items.message: This message has been issued because some minor flooding to riverside roads and footpaths is likely from now, 8am Friday 24th November, and for at least the next 24 hours. Water levels continue to remain high in this area. The forecast tides at Great Yarmouth will restrict the freshwater river drainage out to sea resulting in higher than normal water levels within the Broads until the current high tides pass. We expect to see high water levels in Brundall and Reedham riverside areas. The current series of high spring tides will continue for the next few days and further warning messages may be issued. After the weekend the tides will start to fall away, allowing the freshwater river flows to drain out to sea at low tide as normal again. Take care on waterside roads and footpaths, and don't put yourself in unnecessary danger. We are closely monitoring the situation. We will update this message by 10am Saturday 25th November, or as the situation changes.

items.description: The Suffolk coast at Southwold
items.message: This message has been issued because some minor flooding to coastal roads and footpaths may occur today, due to high tides between 6pm and 8pm, Friday 24th November. Strong winds and spring tides may cause large waves, and spray overtopping on the coast. We expect high tide levels at the harbourside in Southwold. The detailed forecast for those that use it is for a peak level at Lowestoft of 2.19 mAODN at 7pm, Friday 24th November, which is 1.29m above tide tables, wind Force 7, northerly. (mAODN is height above average sea level, for more info refer to local tide table). The tide on Saturday 25th November at 7am is also currently forecast to be a Flood Alert, we will send a new message before that tide. Take care on coastal roads and footpaths, and don't put yourself in unnecessary danger. We are monitoring the situation and further alerts or warnings may be issued.  We will update this message by 9pm today, Friday 24th November.

items.message: Tidal levels have reduced below alert threshold for the next tide, however the tide on Friday 24th November at 9:45pm is currently forecast to be a Flood Alert, possibly Flood Warning, we will send a new message before that tide. Strong winds and spring tides may cause large waves, and spray overtopping on the coast.  Continue to take care on waterside roads and footpaths, and don't put yourself in unnecessary danger. We will continue to monitor levels closely.

items.description: The tidal Deben estuary
items.message: This message has been issued because some minor flooding to coastal roads and footpaths may occur today, due to high tides between 8:45pm and 10:45pm, Friday 24th November. Strong winds and spring tides may cause large waves, and spray overtopping on the coast. Tide levels will be high around the boat yard in Felixstowe Ferry hamlet at the end of Ferry Road, and along riverside areas in Woodbridge and Waldringfield, as well as in surrounding marshland. The detailed forecast for those that use it is for a peak level at Harwich of 3.04 mAODN at 9:45pm, Friday 24th November, which is 1.23m above tide tables, wind Force 6, north westerly. (mAODN is height above average sea level, for more info refer to local tide table). The current series of high spring tides will remain over the next few days. Take care on coastal roads and footpaths, and don't put yourself in unnecessary danger. We are monitoring the situation and further alerts or warnings may be issued.  We will update this message by 9am tomorrow, Saturday 25th November.

items.description: North Sea coast from Staithes to Whitby including tidal River Esk
items.message: Strong winds and high tides are expected to cause large waves and spray overtopping along the North Sea coast from Staithes to Whitby, including Sandsend and tidal River Esk. The main area of concern is Sandsend. Overtopping waves and spray are expected between 12:30pm and 6pm on Friday, 24/11/2023 and 1:30am and 6am on Saturday morning, 25/11/2023. Avoid beaches, promenades, coastal footpaths and roads as large waves and sea spray could be dangerous. We will continue to monitor the forecast and may re-issue this alert for additional tides if necessary. This message will be updated by 7pm on 24/11/2023, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Isolated low lying properties along the tidal River Waveney
items.message: This message has been issued because flooding of homes and businesses is possible from 11pm this evening, Thursday 23rd November, and for at least the next 24 hours. Water levels continue to remain high in this area. The forecast tides at Great Yarmouth will restrict the freshwater river drainage out to sea, resulting in higher than normal water levels within the Broads until the current high tides pass. Areas most at risk are in St Olaves, Somerleyton, Burgh St Peter, Oulton Broad and Beccles. Roads likely to be affected include Beccles Road at St Olaves, Geldeston Lock Lane, Gillingham Dam and Fen Lane in Beccles. The current series of high spring tides will continue for the next few days and further warning messages may be issued. After the weekend the tides will start to fall away, allowing the freshwater river flows to drain out to sea at low tide as normal again. Be ready to take action to protect your property if flooding is expected. We are closely monitoring the situation.  We will update this message by 1pm Friday 24th November, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Riverside properties along the tidal River Yare including Cantley, Brundall and Reedham
items.message: This message has been issued because flooding of homes and businesses is possible from 11pm this evening, Thursday 23rd November, and for at least the next 24 hours. The forecast tides at Gt Yarmouth will restrict the freshwater river drainage out to sea resulting in higher than normal water levels within the Broads until the current high tides pass. The current series of high spring tides will continue for the next few days and further warning messages may be issued. After the weekend the tides will start to fall away, allowing the freshwater river flows to drain out to sea at low tide as normal again. items.description: Tidal Thames riverside from Putney Bridge to Teddington Weir
items.eaAreaName: Kent, South London and East Sussex

floodArea.county: Greater London, Hammersmith and Fulham, Hounslow, Richmond upon Thames, Wandsworth

items.message:
River levels are expected to be high as a result of spring tides.

The next high tide at Richmond at 10:30 on 24/11/23, may result in brief low-level flooding of riverside roads and open spaces.

Astronomical tide levels are rising. The river flow at Teddington Weir is high for this time of year at 123 cubic metres per second and is falling slowly. We anticipate the flows to remain high for the next few days.

We are closely monitoring the situation.

This message will be updated by 13:00 on 21/11/23, or as the situation changes, as subsequent tides over the next couple of days may be higher.

Overtopping waves and spray are expected between 2pm and 6pm on Friday afternoon, 24/11/2023, particularly around Kilnsea village. Avoid beaches, promenades, coastal footpaths and roads as large waves and sea spray could be dangerous. We will continue to monitor the forecast and may re-issue this alert for additional tides if necessary. This message will be updated by 7pm on 24/11/2023, or as the situation changes.

Overtopping waves and spray are expected between 2:30pm and 7pm on Friday 24/11/2023, particularly around Marine Drive and Royal Albert Drive in Scarborough. Avoid beaches, promenades, coastal footpaths and roads as large waves and sea spray could be dangerous. We will continue to monitor the forecast and may re-issue this alert for additional tides if necessary. This message will be updated by 7pm on 24/11/2023, or as the situation changes.

items.description: The Norfolk coast from Caister to Gorleston, including Great Yarmouth
items.message: This message has been issued because some minor flooding to coastal roads and footpaths may occur today due to high tides between 5:45pm and 7:45pm, Friday 24th November. Strong winds and spring tides may cause large waves, and spray overtopping on the coast. We expect high tide levels at Gorleston-on-Sea and water on towpaths and quaysides throughout Great Yarmouth. The detailed forecast for those that use it is for a peak level at Great Yarmouth of 2.08 mAODN at 6:45pm, Friday 24th November, which is 1.24m above tide tables, wind Force 7, northerly. (mAODN is height above average sea level, for more info refer to local tide table). The current series of high spring tides will continue for the next few days. Take care on coastal roads and footpaths, and don't put yourself in unnecessary danger. We are monitoring the situation and further alerts or warnings may be issued.  We will update this message by 9pm today, Friday 24th November.

items.description: The Suffolk coast from Lowestoft to Bawdsey
items.message: This message has been issued because some minor flooding to coastal roads and footpaths may occur today, due to high tides between 6pm and 8pm, Friday 24th November. Strong winds and spring tides may cause large waves, and spray overtopping on the coast. We expect to see high water levels in Lake Lothing in Lowestoft as well as high sea levels along the Suffolk Coast, impacting on beach access points. The detailed forecast for those that use it is for a peak level at Lowestoft of 2.19 mAODN at 7pm, Friday 24th November, which is 1.29m above tide tables, wind Force 7, northerly. (mAODN is height above average sea level, for more info refer to local tide table). The current series of high spring tides will continue for the next few days. Take care on coastal roads and footpaths, and don't put yourself in unnecessary danger. We are monitoring the situation and further alerts or warnings may be issued.  We will update this message by 9pm today, Friday 24th November.

items.description: North Sea at Sandsend
items.message: Strong winds and high tides are expected to cause large waves and spray overtopping along the North Sea at Sandsend. Waves are forecast to overtop coastal defences at the sea front (A174) and properties adjacent to the road between 12:30pm and 6pm on Friday afternoon, 24/11/2023. Stay away from beaches, promenades, coastal footpaths and roads as large waves and sea spray will be dangerous. Start acting on your flood plan if you have one. Plan driving routes to coastal roads, which may be flooded. We will continue to monitor the forecast and may re-issue this warning for additional tides if necessary. This message will be updated by 4pm on 24/11/2023, or as the situation changes.

items.description: The Norfolk coast from Eccles on Sea, to and including, Winterton-on-Sea
items.message: This message has been issued because some minor flooding to coastal roads and footpaths may occur tomorrow morning due to high tides between 3:30pm and 5.30pm, Friday 24th November. Strong winds and spring tides may cause large waves, and spray overtopping on the coast. High tides will mean flood gates will be closed restricting normal access to beaches around Eccles on Sea, and Sea Palling. The detailed forecast for those that use it is for a peak level at Cromer of 3.02 mAODN at 4:30pm, Friday 24th November, which is 1.19m above tide tables, wind Force7, north - westerly. (mAODN is height above average sea level, for more info refer to local tide table)  The current series of high spring tides will continue for the next few days. Take care on coastal roads and footpaths, and don't put yourself in unnecessary danger. We are monitoring the situation and further alerts or warnings may be issued.  We will update this message by 6pm today, Friday 24th November.
